questions.text: A 55y/o female presented to ortho OPD with history of pain in both knees and back. the doctor sent investigation for vit D deficiency, which molecule is measured in this investigation?

choices.text: all of the above can be measured.

questions.solution:
Vit D –
• Formation of vit D starts in skin from cholesterol. In skin cholesterol is converted to cholecalciferol which is than transported to liver where 25- hydroxylase converts it into 25-dehydroxy cholecalciferol
• 25(OH) D3 is than converted to 1,25- di hydroxycholecalciferol by 1alfa hydroxylase in kidney which is also the rate limiting enzyme of formation of vit D.
• Most potent form of vit D is 1,25 dihydroxy cholecalciferol but half life and serum value of this compound is way less then 25-hydroxycholechalciferol. That’s why 25-hydroxy vit D is preferred for vit D assay.

questions.text: Which statements are wrong regarding Rapaport luebering cycle?I. It occurs only in RBCsII. Total 2 ATPs are formed in 1 cycleIII. 2,3 BPG (BIPHOSPHOGCYRIC ACID) helps in oxygen loading to hemoglobin.IV. 10 % of glucose entering RBCs enter Rapoport cycle.
questions.solution:
Rapaport pathway
This pathway occurs in RBC’s only , for production of 2,3BPG which regulates the loading and unloading of oxygen molecules from hemoglobin.
10% of total glucose entering RBC is used in this pathway, there is total zero production of ATP.
An increase in 2,3BPG shifts the curve to right side and helps in unloading and vice versa.

questions.text: A newborn was born with congenital anomalies, further investigation revealed pt had trisomy 21(down’s syndrome), which of the following is best technique for diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Karyotyping-
• Karyotyping is technique in which mitosis is arrested in metaphase using colchicine and chromosomes are stained with giemsa stain.
• Different size, shape, number, position of chromosome and centromere can be determined , so this is the best method for confirming trisomy and monosomy defects.
• In case of down’s syndrome karyograph will show 1 extra 21st chromosome.

questions.text: During well fed state which of the following mechanism is inhibited under the influence of insulin?I. GluconeogenesisII. Glycolysis III. Lipolytic activity of hormone sensitive lipase (HSL).IV. Glycogenesis V. Glycogenolysis
questions.solution:
Well-fed state
In well fed state there is excess glucose present in our body, insulin is the main regularizing hormone. Insulin dephosphorylates the enzymes which are active under influence of insulin.

Following pathways are activated in fed state
1. Glycolysis
2. Glycogenesis
3. Fatty acid synthesis
4. Pyruvate dehydrogenase pathway.

following pathways are inhibited in fed state.
1. Gluconeogenesis
2. Lipolytic activity of HSL
3. Glycogenolysis

questions.text: When does peripheral chemoreceptors respond to hypoxia?
questions.solution:
Hypoxia stimulates peripheral chemoreceptors
and then that will send signals via IX and X Nerve to
respiratory centre. Hypoxia does not drive the
ventilation until PO2 has fallen below 60 mmHg
(Normal 100 mmHg), that is so strong that it will override the effects of CO2 washout on Central Chemoreceptors – then Hypoxia will continue to drive the breathing.

increase in Na + - K. ATPase (pump) activity. It is an
active transport process; it is estimated to spend
about 40 % of the total energy expenditure by the
cells.

questions.text: Which of the following are rapidly acting mechanisms in the Arterial BP Regulation?I. Baroreceptor reflexII. Chemoreceptor reflexIII. RAS Aldosterone SystemIV. Epinephrine secreted from adrenal medullaV. Capillary fluid shift mechanism
questions.solution:
Rapidly Acting Mechanism (Acts Within Seconds To Minutes):
• Baroreceptor reflex(Most Rapid)
• Chemoreceptor reflex
• CNS is ischemic response
• Epinephrine secreted from adrenal medulla

Intermediate Acting Mechanisms (Few Minute To Hours):
• Capillary fluid shift mechanism
• Stress relaxation and reverse stress relaxation
• Renin-Angiotensin mediated vasoconstriction (Max. Rise In BP)

Long-Term Mechanisms (3-10 Days):
• Renal fluid conservation mechanism by ADH, ANP, Aldosterone
• RAS -Aldosterone System

questions.text: which statements regarding Beta oxidation lipids are false?I. Beta oxidation occurs in peroxisomes II. It is a catabolic process in which two carbon atoms are cleaved from lipid molecule.III. The chain is broken between alfa (2) and beta (3).IV. 1 round of beta oxidation yields 1 FADH2, 2NADH and 1acetyl CoA.
questions.solution:
Beta-oxidation-


• Beta oxidation is main pathway for lipid metabolism occurring in mitochondria and most common fatty acid undergoing beta oxidation is palmitic acid.
• Cleavage of bond takes place between alpha 2 and beta 3 carbon units.
• There are 3 steps in beta oxidation
a) activation of fatty acid
b) transport of fatty acid to mitochondria
c) beta oxidation.
• This is a catabolic process as it cleaves 2 carbon atoms from fatty acid
• Number of bets oxidation is= (number of carbon atoms/2) – 1
• One beta oxidation produce 1 NADH, 1 FADH2 AND 1 Acetyl CoA.

questions.text: Match the following examples with respective types. I. Alpha KG dehydrogenase inhibited by arsenite a) competitive inhibition II. HMG-CoA inhibited by statins b) non-competitive III. Placental ALP inhibited by phenylalanine c) uncompetitiveIV. COX enzymes inhibited by aspirin. d) suicidal inhibition

choices.text: I – B, II – A , III – C , IV- D
I- B , II – C , III- A ,IV – D
I- C , II – B , III – A, IV – D
I- A , II- B , III- C, IV- D

questions.solution:
Alpha KG dehydrogenase is non-competitively inhibited by arsenite , as inhibitor doesn’t compete with substrate for attachment to enzyme and also inhibitor is not a structural analogue of substrate.
HMG-CoA is inhibited competitively as inhibitor competes with substrate for enzyme.
Placental ALP is inhibited uncompetitively by phenylalanine
COX enzyme is irreversibly inhibited by aspirin as an example of suicide inhibition.

questions.text: According to McNaughten’s rule under section 84 of IPC insane person is not responsible for his/her crime, which of the following case will not get benefit from this section?
questions.solution:
Mcnaughten’s rule states that, to establish a defense on the ground of insanity, it must be clearly proved that, at time of committing of the act, the party accused was laboring under such a defect of reason, from disease of mind, as not to know it, that he did not know the nature and quality of the act he was doing; or if he did not know it, that he did not know he was doing what was wrong.

Following cases are benefited from this rule.

How to remember- “SPIT-DO”

    • Somnambulism
    • Post traumatic automatization
    • Involuntary drug intoxication
    • Twilight state
    • Delirium tremens
    • Oneiroid state

questions.text:
A person presented with history of dog bite on the uncovered surface of his right leg. There is minor abrasion without bleeding. Consider following statements
I)The bite should be taken as category 1 contact
II)The bite requires local treatment of wound
III)The person requires immediate vaccination
IV) The person requires immediate administration of rabies immunoglobulin
Which of following statements are correct?
questions.solution:
→ CLASS I BITES : No prophylaxisrequired.

  • Licks over intact skin

→ CLASS II BITES: Post exposure prophylaxisrequired.

  • Licks over broken skin
  • No oozing of Blood

→ CLASS III BITES : Post exposure prophylaxis+ Igs

  • Facial Bites
  • Constant oozing of blood
  • Untraceable animal after bite
  • Wild animals bites

CLASS I BITES : No prophylaxisrequired.

  • Licks over intact skin

MANAGEMENT 1. Wound shouldnever be stitchedimmediately to prevent additional trauma that may help in spread of the virus in the deeper tissue. 2. “If suturing is necessary, then it has to be done after 24-48 hrs later, applying minimum stitches under the coverage of anti rabies serum locally” 3. Cleansing – wound should be scrubbed well immediately withsoap & water– soap kills the virus effectively. 4. Chemical treatment- wound is treated with quaternary ammonium compounds (like cetavlon or tincture iodine). 5. Category III (Major risk): Recommended prophylaxis (WHO)- Wound management, Rabies immunoglobulin, Rabies vaccine, Observe the dog for 10 days.

questions.text: A 25 years old female complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, and b/l nasal blockage for one year. She has a history of asthma and allergy. On examination, multiple ethmoidal polyps are noted with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions in both the nasal cavities. A biopsy is taken and the material is cultured which shows the growth of many hyphae with dichotomous branching typically at 45 degrees. Which of the following is the most likely responsible organism?
questions.solution:
The most likely responsible organism is Aspergillus fumigatus.

1. Key points towards diagnosis:

  • Recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, bilateral nasal blockade.
  • History of asthma and allergy
  • Hyphae with dichotomous branching at 45 degree

2. All points go towards Aspergillus infection.

  • Most common type of fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses are due to Aspergillus.
  • Aspergillus has septate hyphae that branch typically at 45 degrees (V-shaped).

3. Hyphae with dichotomous branching at 45 degrees

Answers to other options:

  • Broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching seen in members of Zygomycetes. i.e Rhizopus and Mucor
  • Candida: Gram-positive oval budding yeast cell with pseudohyphae.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presented to the pediatric ED with his mother. The child can be heard crying inside the waiting/patient room, has both hands bandaged and wrapped. According to the mother, unwitnessed event but the child likely grabbed grates on an old wood-burning stove. The child immediately screamed out, parents grabbed him and flushed hands under cool water. Wrapped child’s hands in towels and brought to ED. On examination, the hands looked as follows (image). Probably the burn involvement is up to:
questions.solution:
First-degree (superficial) burns:
• Involves only the epidermis
• The burn site is red, painful, dry, and with no blisters
• They have an intact epidermal barrier
• They do not result in scarring

Second-degree (partial thickness) burns:
• Second-degree burns involve the epidermis and part of the upper (papillary) dermis layer of skin.
• The burn site appears red, blistered, and may be swollen and painful
• Classified into superficial and deep
• In superficial second degree burns, the burn depth goes no deeper than the papillary dermis
• Superficial second degree burns spontaneously reepithelialize from retained epidermal structures in the rete ridges, hair follicles and sweat glands in 1 to 2 weeks
• Deep second degree burns into the reticular dermis appear pale and mottled, do not blanch to touch but remain painful to pinprick
• These burns heal in 2 to 5 weeks by re epithelialization from hair follicles and sweat gland keratinocytes , often with severe scarring as a result to the loss of dermis

Third-degree (full thickness) burns:
• Third-degree burns destroy the epidermis and dermis and may go into the subcutaneous tissue.
• They are hard, leathery, painless and non blanching

Fourth degree burns:
• Fourth degree burns also damage the underlying soft tissue
• There is no sensation in the area since the nerve endings are destroyed

Fifth degree burns
• They extend through muscle to bone

Sixth degree burns
• Charring bone

choices.text: Mc Roberts maneuver for shoulder dystocia
Gaskins maneuver for rotation of baby.

questions.solution:
Corkscrew maneuver.

Technique:

1. Insert fingers into the patient’s vagina

2. Check shoulder placement

3. Place at least two fingers (index and middle) on the anterior aspect of the fetal posterior shoulder

4. Apply pressure to abduct/extend the posterior shoulder and rotate the fetal body 180°

(a) After 90° the practitioner may need to switch hands in order to complete the full 180° turn

5. This movement rotates the anterior shoulder from under the symphysis pubis and releases the impaction (shoulder dystocia)

  4. Non-compliance on the part of the patient.

Atrophic nonunion-

  • Osteogenesis seems to have ceased.
  • The bone ends are tapered or rounded with no indication of new bone formation.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly represents the formula of Modified Shock Index?
questions.solution:
Shock index Modified shock index
  • Heart rate divided by Systolic BP
  • Better marker for assessing severity of shock than heart rate & BP alone
  • Utility in trauma patients, sepsis, obstetrics, myocardial infarction, stroke & other acute critical illnesses.
  • Correlated with need for interventions such as blood transfusion & invasive procedure including operations
  • SI is known as a hemodynamic stability indicator
  • SI does not take into account the diastolic BP
  • Heart rate divided by Mean arterial pressure
  • High MSI indicates a value of stroke volume & low systemic vascular resistance a sign of hypodynamic circulation
  • Low MSI indicates a hyper dynamic state
  • MSI has been considered a better marker than SI for mortality rate prediction

questions.text: A 30 years old male complains of loss of erection; he has low testosterone levels and high prolactin levels in blood; What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
30 year old male has low testosterone levels which may be due to hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism , testicular failure or prolactinoma. But since the prolactin levels are high, prolactinoma which is a pituitary adenoma is the cause for low testosterone and loss of erection
Pituitary adenomas
Pituitary adenomas arise from the anterior pituitary gland. They may be microadenoma < 10 mm in size or macroadenomas >10 mm in size. They may be functional or non functional. The most common endocrine syndromes produced by functional tumours include Cushing’s disease(ACTH) , Forbes Albright syndrome (prolactin) and acromegaly (growth hormone) . Thirty percent of adenomas are prolactinomas, 20% are non functioning, 15% secrete growth hormone and 10% secrete ACTH

Features of note in the initial assessment include any


• History of galactorrhoea in females and impotence in males, infertility in both (suggestive of prolactinoma)
• Cushingoid (classic hyperpigmentation of the skin and mucous membrane, ecchymosis, and purple striae pointing to ACTH secreting tumours or
• Acromegalic features pointing to growth hormone secreting tumours


Baseline assessment of pituitary function should include serum prolactin( levels more than 150ng/mL is considered diagnostic of prolactinoma) , follicle stimulating hormone and luteinising hormone together with testosterone in males or oestradiol in females, thyroid function tests and fasting serum growth hormone and cortisol

Prolactinomas are managed initially with dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine and cabergoline. Compression of the chiasm with any evidence of visual compromise is the main indication for urgent surgical intervention. Surgical resection is usually performed transnasally via a transsphenoidal approach. Complications of surgery include CSF leak , pituitary insufficiency and diabetes insipidus

Craniopharyngiomas are benign cystic lesions that occur in the sellar region most frequently in children. A second peak of incidence also exists around 50 years of age. Symptoms result from compression of adjacent structures, especially the optic chiasm. Pituitary or hypothalamic dysfunction or hydrocephalus may develop. Treatment is primary surgical

questions.text: Headlight in the fog is classical description of?
questions.solution:
It is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular protozoan.
It accounts for about half the cases of posterior uveitis in immunocompetent individuals due to reaction at previously inactive cyst containing scars. Headlight in the fog is classical description of white retinal inflammatory nidus viewed through viritis.

questions.text: A 34y/o female gave birth to 2 babies and suffered from PPH (Post-partum hemorrhage ) due to an atonic uterus. Now pt presents with difficulty in breastfeeding, amenorrhea, low blood pressure, weight gain, difficulty staying warm and fatigue. What could be the possible reason for this condition?

choices.text: PPH causes necrosis of the pituitary gland, which manifest as hypothyroidism, decreased FSH, LH and decreased prolactin hormones.
PPH causes severe anemia which manifests as given symptoms.
Post-partum blues or depression can present as give symptom
PPH causes HEELP syndrome which is the cause of this presentation.

questions.solution:
Sheehan syndrome.

  • PPH causes blood loss which affects the blood supply of the pituitary and causes necrosis of the gland.
  • So hormones or pituitary gland decreases which manifest as hypothyroidism (low TSH) , low prolactin levels so the difficulty in breast feeding, adrenal insufficiency so the low blood pressure.
  • Treatment of Sheehan syndrome is the replacement of pituitary hormones

questions.text: A 45 year old female patient to ORTHO opd with complaint of abnormal gait, hip instability and increased lumbar lordosis. She gave history of falling from stairs around 6 months back. The doctor thinks probably it is a case of flexion contracture of the hip. Which of the following test can be useful in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Thomas test:

  • Done for hip flexion deformities
  • When the hip of the opposite side is flexed lumbar lordosis is obliterated by rotation of pelvis on obliteration of lumbar lordosis, flexion deformity of hip becomes prominent.
  • Lumbar lordosis is compensated up to 30 degree hip flexion

If flexed > 30 degree the flexion deformity of the abnormal side of hip will be prominent which was hidden by lumbar lordosis

Other tests

  • Adsons test : It is a provocative test for Thoracic outlet syndrome
  • Muller test : It is used to find posterior cruciate ligament disruption and posterior knee laxity
  • Trendelenburg test : It is used to assess the weakness or paralysis of gluteus medius muscle

questions.text: A 45 year old male chronic alcoholic came to the OPD with complaints of hemetemesis, abdominal distension and jaundice. He was diagnosed as a case of alcoholic cirrhosis. All of the following scoring systems can be used to assess whether the patient is a suitable candidate for liver transplantation except:-
questions.solution:
MPI is myocardial perfusion imaging using radionuclide (Tc99m) to detect bundle branch blocks, baseline ST segment depressions,drug effects
Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score, Model for End Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score & Pediatric End Stage Liver Disease (PELD) MEGX(Monoethylglycinexylidine ) score are used in liver transplantation.
The MELD score is based on bilirubin and creatinine levels and the international normalized ratio (INR). It predicts survival in a cirrhosis patients, especially those on the waiting list for a liver transplant. A minimum MELD score of 18 is necessary to have a survival benefit post-transplant
Pediatric donor livers are distributed to pediatric patients preferentially. The scoring used in pediatric patients is referred to as the pediatric end-stage liver disease (PELD) score
CTP score is based on five variables - Bilirubin level, albumin level, INR,encephalopathy and ascites
The MEGX is rapid and simple test which can assess the function of liver and widely used for liver transplantation in critical care medicines. It measures MEGX formation after the administration of lidocaine, has been shown to be approximately 80% sensitive and specific in diagnosing cirrhosis

questions.text: In ECG narrow QRS complex is seen, what could be probable diagnosis?

  • Delta Wave - WPW
  • Osborn Wave - Hypothermia
  • Wide Complex QRS - Premature Ventricular Complex / Ventricular Tachycardia / Torsades de pointes (TDP)
  • M pattern in Peak of QRS - Bundle branch block
